# Cultural and Individual Diversity {#diversity}

Like [ethics](#ethics), considerations of cultural and individual diversity are relevant to all of our domains as psychologists, including (but not limited to) research, teaching, assessment, intervention, and supervision.\index{diversity}
As a result, I have discussed important considerations about diversity throughout the book, including the chapters on [validity](#validity), [evidence-based assessment](#evidence-based), and [test bias](#bias).\index{diversity}
At the same time, given the importance of cultural and individual diversity, I also provide this section, which is devoted more fully to these issues within the assessment context.\index{diversity}
Diverse samples provide stronger tests of theories and better generalizability of findings ([external validity](#externalValidity)).\index{diversity}
On the assessment side, we need measures that provide us with the best information, and that are [reliable](#reliability) and [valid](#validity) for all people we use them with.\index{diversity}\index{reliability}\index{validity}
Diversity is a broad concept, and it spans many dimensions of differences among people.\index{diversity}

## Terminology {#terminology-diversity}

### DEI {#dei}

#### Diversity {#deiDiversity}

*Diversity* refers to all aspects of differences between people.\index{diversity}
Diversity is a characteristic of a group, not a characteristic of an individual.\index{diversity}
Thus, a person is not diverse.\index{diversity}
There are many aspects of human difference, including but not limited to race, ethnicity, creed, color, sex, gender, gender identity, sexual orientation, socioeconomic status, language, culture, national origin, religion/spirituality, age, (dis)ability, military/veteran status, personality, political perspective, and associational preferences.\index{diversity}

Having a diverse group (e.g., of participants, clients, patients, etc.) is insufficient.\index{diversity}
It is also important to make sure that we take steps for all groups to feel included ([inclusion](#inclusion)) and to thrive ([equity](#equity)).\index{diversity}\index{inclusion}\index{equity}

#### Equity {#equity}

*Equity* refers to [fair](#fairness) and just practices and policies that ensure everyone can thrive.\index{equity}\index{fairness}
Equity is different from equality.\index{equity}\index{equality}
*Equality* involves treating everyone equally (i.e., treating everyone the same).\index{equality}
However, due to structural inequities—historic and current (e.g., structural racism and patriarchy)—some people are disadvantaged and marginalized more so than others.
Structural racism refers to "the normalization and legitimization of an array of dynamics—historical, cultural, institutional, and interpersonal—that routinely advantage non-Latinx White persons while producing cumulative and chronic adverse outcomes for Black and other people with minoritized identities in housing, education, employment, health care, criminal justice, and psychology." [@Byrd2021, p. 279].
Patriarchal societies reflect society's long history of wage gaps, gender discrimination, violence against women, etc.
Treating people equally (equality) does not allow everyone to thrive given these different experiences and unequal access to opportunities.\index{equality}
Thus, equity seeks to help everyone thrive, including those who are marginalized with fewer access to opportunities.\index{equity}

#### Inclusion {#inclusion}

*Inclusion* refers to providing a community where all members are and feel respected, have a sense of belonging, and are able to participate and achieve their potential.\index{inclusion}

### Aspects of Difference {#aspectsOfDifference}

There many aspects of difference.\index{diversity}
However, identifying labels to capture these differences can be challenging.
"Asian" is an overly broad term.\index{diversity}
There are more than 4 billion people from Asian countries, and considerable heterogeneity.\index{diversity}
"Hispanic" is based on language (i.e., a person from a Spanish speaking country), whereas "Latino/a/x" and "African American" are based on geography (i.e., a person from a Latin American country).\index{diversity}
Traditional classifications of race/ethnicity by the National Institutes of Health miss groups that may be important to distinguish, including Arab, Middle Eastern, or North African (AMENA) populations.\index{diversity}

Labels by the 2020 U.S. Census attempt to be more precise than traditional classifications of race and ethnicity by the National Institutes of Health.\index{diversity}
For the classification of "Hispanic, Latino, or Spanish origin" in the 2020 U.S. Census, see Figure \@ref(fig:census-hispanic).\index{diversity}
Notice how the question distinguishes between identities of people from (or whose ancestors were from) various countries, including Mexico, Puerto Rico, Cuba, etc.\index{diversity}
